docs.text: " there will be another , " the ads for this sequel proclaimed , and why not ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: true , brandon lee is dead , but there would be no reason for him to appear in a followup to 1994's the crow , anyway .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the idea of spinning artist james o'barr's original comic book series into a sequel franchise revolves around the notion that a different startled soul would come back from the dead in each movie , taking its own righteous vengeance against the world .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: given that basic framework , the story could move in any number of directions .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: of course , it doesn't .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: stubbornly , the crow : city of angels backtracks to the beginning of the previous film , when lee's eric draven found himself drawn back out of his grave to do a charles bronson on the thugs who tortured him and his girlfriend to death .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: i remember the first film primarily as a harrowing exercise in brutality .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in flashback , we see the most excruciating crimes exacted on eric and his lover , and then we watch in real-time as eric pays each perpetrator back in kind .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's loud and repetitive , true , a sadist's delight -- but it's also horrifying and fascinating .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: city of angels gives us more of the same , but less skillfully .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there's an audience guaranteed for a film like this , although bad reviews and poor word-of-mouth will likely ensure that it won't be much of a success .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in fact , miramax subsidiary dimension films was so fearful of the critical reaction to this picture that reviewers were shut out of advance screenings .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: ( i've never understood the reasoning behind this tactic , since good notices have never been key to the success of movies like the crow . )
docs.label: negative

docs.text: so much for any confidence in the worthiness of their followup .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: this time , ashe ( french-accented actor vincent perez ) is retrieved from his watery death ( he and his young son were shackled together , shot , and then thrown off a pier ) by the crow who serves as his link between the worlds of the living and the dead .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: perez might have some screen presence if he's given something to do with himself , but here he's simply thrown in front of the camera as a pretty face .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: at first , he's shivery and frightened , but he quickly recovers from the shock of his own death and becomes a badass biker from beyond the grave .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: he's befriended by sarah ( mia kirshner ) , presumably an older version of the child who narrated the first film .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: kirshner , so beguiling in exotica , is here an exquisitely photographed blank .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: tattooed with angels' wings , sarah is just about as lovely as women come , but she serves no purpose , not even as seductress .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the gang of punks who killed ashe are ostensibly commanded by judah ( richard brooks ) , but a far more interesting choice as leader would have been iggy pop , who plays a gaunt fellow named curve .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: iggy , all bones , veins , and drawl , is the only one who seems to have shared in the aesthetic of ruin that defines this film .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: like all good things here , he's dispatched too soon and without much imagination .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in the meantime , we're subjected to tedious glimpses of judah's compound , where bondage is the order of the day and hot wax is poured over naked bodies in s&m fantasies that would seem shy of the cutting edge even if they weren't distinctly secondhand .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: even the soundtrack is tired .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: more than anything i've seen from hollywood lately , city of angels smacks baldly of product -- it's a movie with a lousy script but a great look .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: critics have been quick to fault the direction of mtv veteran tim pope , but his work isn't that bad per se .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: he's got a good eye , and some intriguing visual ideas -- if anything , this movie has a few too many scenes of ridiculously striking imagery .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: his major stylistic failing is that he can't seem to direct an action scene , and the quick , nonsensical cutting that ensues is reminiscent of a low budget kung fu movie .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: but as director , he must also shoulder the blame for the little screenplay that wasn't , the performers who couldn't , and an apparent lack of ideas on the parts of everyone involved .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: who bought david s . goyer's anemic script , anyway ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the producers of this crow were either too dim to realize their story was doomed to be a hollow rehash , or too cynical to figure their audience would know the difference .
docs.label: negative
